sen.j: 圓照寺（えんしょうじ, 円照寺）は、奈良市山町にある尼寺。
sen.e: Ensho-ji Temple is a nunnery temple located in Yama-cho, Nara City.
Ensho-ji Temple is a nunnery temple located in Yama-cho, Nara City.
Ensho-ji Temple is a nunnery temple located in Yama-cho, Nara City.

sen.j: 山号は普門山（ふもんざん）。
sen.e: Sango (the name of a group of Buddhist temples) is Fumonzan.
Sango (the name of a group of Buddhist temples) is Fumonzan.
Sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Fumonzan.

sen.j: 斑鳩町の中宮寺、佐保の法華寺と共に大和三門跡と呼ばれる臨済宗妙心寺派に属する門跡寺院。
sen.e: It is a monzeki temple (a temple of high rank where members of imperial family and nobility enter the priesthood) which belongs to Myoshin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect called Yamato Three Monzeki as well as Chugu-ji Temple in Ikaruga-cho and Hokke-ji Temple in Saho were.

Ensho-ji Temple is a monzeki temple (a temple of high rank where members of imperial family and nobility enter the priesthood) which belongs to the Myoshin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect called Yamato Three Monzeki as well as Chugu-ji Temple in Ikaruga-cho and Hokke-ji Temple in Saho were.

Ensho-ji Temple is a monzeki temple (a temple of high rank where members of Imperial Family and nobility enter the priesthood) which belongs to the Myoshin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect called Yamato Three Monzeki as well as Chugu-ji Temple in Ikaruga-cho and Hokke-ji Temple in Saho were.

sen.j: 華道の「山村御流」の家元でもある。
sen.e: It is also an iemoto (the head family of a school) of a flower arrangement school, "Yamamura Goryu".
The temple is also an iemoto (the head family of a school) of a flower arrangement school, "Yamamura Goryu".
The temple is also an iemoto (the head family of a school) of a flower arrangement school, 'Yamamura Goryu.'
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: 別名、山村御殿。
sen.e: Another name is Yamamura Goten Palace,
Another name for it is the Yamamura Goten Palace,
Another name for it is the Yamamura Goten Palace.
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: 三島由紀夫の小説『豊饒の海』に再三登場する「月修寺」は、圓照寺をモデルに描かれているとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Ensho-ji Temple was a model of "Gesshu-ji Temple", which often appears in Yukio MISHIMA's novel, "Hojo no Umi (The Sea of Fertility)".
It is said that Ensho-ji Temple was a model of "Gesshu-ji Temple", which often appears in Yukio MISHIMA's novel, "Hojo no Umi (The Sea of Fertility)".
It is said that Ensho-ji Temple was a model of 'Gesshu-ji Temple,' which often appears in Yukio MISHIMA's novel, "Hojo no Umi" (The Sea of Fertility).
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。カンマ位置移動しました。

sen.j: （非公開のため拝観不可）
sen.e: (Not available for visitors as it is a closed-door temple.)
(Not available to visitors as it is a closed-door temple.)
(Not available to visitors as it is a closed-door temple.)

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 寛永17年（1640年）、後水尾天皇の第1皇女であった文智女王（幼名、梅宮）が、22歳で仏頂国師を師として出家し、大通文智となる。
sen.e: In 1640, Bunchi Joo (Princess Bunchi) (childhood name Ume-no-miya), who was the first daughter of Emperor Gomizunoo, became Daitsu Bunchi (knowledgeable person, Bunchi) after becoming a nun at the age of 22, regarding Buccho Kokushi (the most reverend priest of the principal Buddha) as her mentor.

In 1640, Bunchi Joo (Princess Bunchi) (childhood name Ume-no-miya), who was the first daughter of Emperor Gomizunoo, became Daitsu Bunchi (knowledgeable person, Bunchi) after becoming a nun at the age of 22, regarding Buccho Kokushi (the most reverend priest of the principal Buddha) as her mentor.

In 1640, Princess Bunchi (childhood name Ume-no-miya), who was the first daughter of Emperor Gomizunoo, became Daitsu Bunchi (knowledgeable person, Bunchi) after becoming a nun at the age of 22, regarding Buccho Kokushi (the most reverend priest of the principal Buddha) as her mentor.

sen.j: 寛永18年（1641年）、大通文智が、京都の修学院の地に草庵を結んだ。
sen.e: In 1641, Daitsu Bunchi made a thatched hut in Shugakuin, Kyoto.
In 1641, Daitsu Bunchi made a thatched hut in Shugakuin, Kyoto.
In 1641, Daitsu Bunchi made a thatched hut in Shugakuin, Kyoto.

sen.j: 明暦2年（1656年）、天皇による修学院離宮の造営によって移転を迫られ、継母である中宮東福門院（徳川秀忠の娘）の助力により、幕府から200石（のちに300石に加増）、金1,000両の寄進を得て、大和国添上郡八嶋の地に移り、八嶋御所と称した。
sen.e: In 1656, it was named Yashima Gosho (Yashima Imperial Palace) after moving to Yashima Village, Sonokami-no-kori County, Yamato Province, which was donated 200 koku (55.6 cubic meters) (later increased to 300 koku (83.4 cubic meters)) and Sen-ryo (a thousand-ryo) of gold by the government with support of her stepmother, Chugu Tofukumonin (a daughter of Hidetada TOKUGAWA) since the hut was forced to relocate due to building Shugakuin Rikyu (Shugakuin Rikyu Imperial Villa) by Emperor.

In 1656, it was named Yashima Gosho (Yashima Imperial Palace) after moving to Yashima Village, Sonokami-no-kori County, Yamato Province, which was donated 200 koku (55.6 cubic meters) (later increased to 300 koku (83.4 cubic meters)) and Sen-ryo (a thousand-ryo) of gold by the government with support of her stepmother, Chugu Tofukumonin (a daughter of Hidetada TOKUGAWA) since the hut was forced to relocate due to building Shugakuin Rikyu (Shugakuin Rikyu Imperial Villa) by Emperor.

In 1656, it was named Yashima Gosho (Yashima Imperial Palace) after moving to Yashima Village, Sonokami-no-kori County, Yamato Province, which was donated 200 koku (55.6 cubic meters) (later increased to 300 koku (83.4 cubic meters)) and Sen-ryo (a thousand-ryo) of gold by the government with support of her stepmother, Chugu Tofukumonin (a daughter of Hidetada TOKUGAWA) since the hut was forced to relocate due to building Shugakuin Rikyu (Shugakuin Rikyu Imperial Villa) by Emperor.

sen.j: 寛文9年（1669年）、現在地に再度移転した。
sen.e: In 1669, it moved again to the current location.
In 1669, it moved again to its current location.
In 1669, it moved again to its current location.
